DOC.HEAD: Romania at a Glance
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here are some facts and figures on Romania:
THE LAND _ Romania covers 91,699 square miles, about the size of Oregon. It is in southeastern Europe, bordered by Hungary, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, the Black Sea and the Soviet Union. Principal rivers are the Danube and its tributary, the Prut; the country is cut by the Carpathian Mountains.

THE PEOPLE _ Romania's population is estimated at 23 million. Bucharest, the capital, is by far the largest city with a population of about 1.9 million. Most of the people are Romanian, but about 10 percent are of Hungarian or German extraction. The dominant religion is the Romanian Orthodox Church.

THE ECONOMY _ Romania is a large exporter of petroleum and natural gas, and has iron, coal and copper mines as well. Chief agricultural products include corn, wheat, wine grapes, sugar beets and potatoes.

HISTORY _ The country obtained full independence from the Turks in 1878 and was proclaimed a kingdom in 1881. Romania was one of the victorious allies in World War I, but after the war it was wracked by political violence. In 1940, Ion Antonescu overthrew King Carol II and established a dictatorship that was aligned with Germany in World War II. As the German Axis foundered, King Michael was able to re-establish a monarchy in 1944, but occupying Soviet troops led to the proclamation of a Communist republic in 1947. Nicolae Ceausescu, 71, took power in 1965 after the death of his mentor, Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej. His 24 years of hard-line rule ended with his ouster Friday.
